questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for one week of abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient noticed an increased amount of watery discharge as well as a prominent odor from the vaginal area after intercourse. The patient is sexually active with one biologically male partner. For contraception, the patient has a copper intrauterine device. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, blood pressure is 116/78 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Chaperoned vaginal examination reveals a thin, grayish-white, watery discharge with a vaginal pH of 4.8. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Saline microscopy of a vaginal sample shows more than 20% of the cell type seen in the image below. A positive whiff test is noted with KOH preparation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?



Image by Dr. Roshan Nasimudeen with Department of Pathology, Government Medical College, Kozikode is licensed under Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge, an abnormal vaginal odor, greater than 20% clue cells on microscopy, vaginal pH above 4.5, and a positive whiff test on KOH preparation consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Copper intrauterine devices are a risk factor for developing bacterial vaginosis.  

Bacterial vaginosis occurs when there is an imbalance of normal flora in the vagina, resulting in overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria, such as Gardnerella vaginalis and Prevotella species, and a loss of Lactobacillus species. Although it is not considered a sexually transmitted infection, sexual practices are often linked to the occurrence of bacterial vaginosis. Identified risk factors include having a new sexual partner, multiple sexual partners, not using condoms, douching, infection with HSV-2, and having an intrauterine device. Characteristic symptoms include a thin, grayish-white vaginal discharge and an abnormal “fishy” odor from the vagina that may be more prominent after sexual intercourse or during menses. Patients may also be asymptomatic.



Option Analysis

✅ Bacterial vaginosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vaginal candidiasis:
Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis is a common infection of the vagina caused by overgrowth of yeast. Patients will often have a thick, white discharge and budding yeast or pseudohyphae on microscopy. This patient has a thin, grayish-white discharge and clue cells on microscopy, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.
❌ Chlamydia infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis and present with a variety of discharge types. Chlamydia trachomatis is an intracellular organism and is not visible by standard saline microscopy. This patient’s vaginal sample has clue cells (caused by Gardnerella vaginalis adhering to vaginal epithelial cells) consistent with bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Gonorrhea infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause cervicitis and present with a variety of types of vaginal discharge; however, this patient’s clue cells on microscopy are more consistent with a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. 
❌ Trichomonas infection:
Incorrect: Infection with Trichomonas vaginalis typically causes a yellow or green discharge and the flagellated, motile protozoa can be seen on wet mount preparation. This patient has a thin, grayish-white discharge and clue cells on microscopy, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents at 28 weeks estimated gestational age for a routine antenatal visit. The patient reports that her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has had two new sexual partners in the past three months and wants to be tested for STIs, including genital herpes. She has no significant past medical history and no prior history of HSV outbreaks. She is taking a prenatal vitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient has no oral lesions. The abdomen is gravid with normal fetal heart sounds. On pelvic speculum examination, there are no anogenital lesions. Anti-HSV-1 and HSV-2 antibodies are present on serum testing. Which of the following best describes this patient’s herpes simplex virus status?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman has had two new sexual partners and would like to be evaluated for sexually transmitted infections, including genital herpes. She states she has had no history of genital herpes lesions, and she has no current lesions. On examination, the patient has no genital lesions, but serum testing shows the presence of antibodies. This indicates past exposure without current infection. The patient may have been asymptomatic with past exposure.   

Testing for exposure to HSV can be performed by obtaining serum antibodies, and results can be used to determine the timing of exposure. Direct viral testing of active lesions should also be performed by unroofing the lesion with a swab and sending collected fluid for viral culture and/or PCR-based HSV antigen detection. Patients with positive serology but without current active lesions, as is the case for this patient, are considered to have prior exposure without current, active disease. Recent exposure and primary (first-time) infection can be confirmed in patients with new active lesions who initially have negative serology and then are found to have positive serology 3-4 weeks after the initial testing. Active lesions and initial positive serology are an indication of a recurrent infection.     

Identifying the specific type of viral antibody present, HSV1 or HSV2 in serum testing, and comparing it to the results of direct viral testing (e.g. PCR) of the lesion can help differentiate a recurrent infection from first infection with a different subtype (nonprimary first episode infection). Recurrent infections are possible even in patients who deny prior history of genital lesions as patients may have had an asymptomatic exposure in the past and now have an active outbreak due to the temporary immunosuppressed state of pregnancy. When lesion and serology testing are both positive but for opposite subtypes, such as when the patient has an HSV1 positive lesion and only HSV2 antibodies OR when the patient has an HSV2 positive lesion and only HSV1 antibodies, then non-primary first episode infection can be diagnosed.   

Option Analysis

✅ Past exposure without active infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent exposure without active infection:
Incorrect: Patients with recent exposure to HSV but without active infection may develop antibodies to HSV within 3-4 weeks. If initial testing is negative for antibodies and the patient has no active lesions, serology testing can be repeated in 3-4 weeks if clinical suspicion is high. If serology is positive at that time, then recent exposure can be confirmed.  
❌ Recurrent infection:
Incorrect: Patients with recurrent infections typically have a history of prior HSV outbreaks, present with one or more new genital lesions, and have positive serology for the same subtype that can be found from viral testing of the new lesion. This patient does not have active lesions and has no prior history of herpes lesions. 
❌ Primary infection:
Incorrect: An early primary infection would present with an active lesion and initially negative serology. This patient does not have active lesions. 
❌ No prior exposure :
Incorrect: This patient has positive serology, which indicates previous exposure despite the absence of a history of active lesions.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 31 weeks estimated gestational age presents to the obstetrics clinic for a routine antenatal visit. The pregnancy has been uneventful, and the patient has no concerns about the pregnancy. However, she recently noticed multiple painful, burning blisters on her vulva. She has no significant past medical history and takes a prenatal vitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. The abdomen is gravid with normal fetal heart sounds. Pelvic examination is notable for lesions depicted in the image below. Additionally, a tender, enlarged lymph node is palpable in the left inguinal area. One of the lesions is unroofed and swabbed for further testing. Serum antibody bloodwork is pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Image sourced from Kohn M. Herpes simplex (HSV) in emergency medicine. Accessed March 6, 2024. http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/783113-overview

choices.text: Wait for results of lesion and serum testing to start acyclovir

questions.solution:
This pregnant woman at 31 weeks’ gestation presents with an active outbreak of genital herpes. HSV testing for the active lesions is pending as is serum antibody testing. While awaiting results, this patient should be treated now with acyclovir or valacyclovir to prevent harm to the fetus and provide symptomatic relief to the mother.    

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection during pregnancy can result in neonatal chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and skin lesions or even disseminated disease if transmitted during the intrapartum period. Therefore, active HSV outbreaks during pregnancy should be treated promptly with acyclovir or valacyclovir.     

For patients with a history of HSV with positive antibodies or those with active HSV, suppressive antiviral medications should begin at 36 weeks of gestation and be continued to delivery. In addition, a sterile speculum examination should be performed at the time of labor to prevent transmission. If, at the time of delivery, active lesions are present or if the patient has had recent prodromal symptoms, a C-section is recommended to reduce the risk of transmission to the newborn via passage through the vaginal canal. The pediatrics team should also be contacted in cases of potential neonatal HSV infection.   

Option Analysis

✅ Start acyclovir now:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start acyclovir at 36 weeks’ gestation:
Incorrect: While suppressive therapy should be started at 36 weeks’ gestation for pregnant patients with HSV to help prevent outbreaks of genital herpes near the time of delivery, this patient should also be treated now for her current outbreak. 
❌ Start acyclovir at 33 weeks’ gestation:
Incorrect: While suppressive therapy should be started at 36 weeks’ gestation for pregnant patients with HSV to help prevent an outbreak of herpes simplex near the time of delivery, this patient should also be treated now for her current outbreak. 
❌ Recommend C-section delivery:
Incorrect: If a patient has an active herpes simplex lesion on speculum exam at time of delivery or has a history of HSV infection and prodromal symptoms at this time of delivery, then C section is recommended. However, it is currently too early to definitively decide on C-section. This patient should first be treated for this current outbreak. 
❌ Wait for results of lesion and serum testing to start acyclovir:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of active genital herpes infection. Waiting to treat would be inappropriate given the risks to the fetus. The patient should be treated with acyclovir now for the current outbreak.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the office because of a missed period. History reveals her last menstrual period was six weeks ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and takes no medications. A urine pregnancy test is obtained in the office and is positive. Laboratory studies reveal a quantitative hCG of 500 mIU/mL. Pelvic examination reveals a closed non-tender cervix and no adnexal masses. A transvaginal ultrasound is obtained and does not definitively show an intrauterine pregnancy or ectopic pregnancy. Two days later, the patient goes to the emergency department with left lower quadrant abdominal pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows guarding and rebound tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Ultrasound shows free fluid in the abdomen. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Recheck hCG and complete blood count

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, positive rebound tenderness, and hemodynamic instability (i.e., tachycardia and hypotension), raising concerns for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.  

Ectopic pregnancy should be suspected in any woman of reproductive age who presents with abdominal pain and/or vaginal bleeding. The first step is to decide if the patient is hemodynamically stable or unstable. In an unstable patient, the first step is to stabilize the patient (e.g., IV fluids), obtain hCG levels, and perform FAST ultrasound. Next, a surgery consult and emergent surgery should commence. In extreme acute cases, hCG may not be obtained before surgery.  

 




Option Analysis

❌ Recheck hCG and complete blood count    :
Incorrect: Conservative measures are not appropriate for any unstable patient with an acute abdomen. IV fluids are necessary to address her hemodynamic instability, and she ultimately requires surgical intervention.
❌ Give intramuscular methotrexate    :
Incorrect: Methotrexate for the treatment of ectopic pregnancy is appropriate after the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy has been confirmed, the patient is hemodynamically stable, hCG concentration is ≤5000 mIU/mL, the mass size is less than 3 cm, and there are no contraindications for the treatment. This patient is currently unstable, which is a contraindication for methotrexate treatment.   
❌ Intravenous fluids and observation    :
Incorrect: Conservative measures are not appropriate for any unstable patient with an acute abdomen. While IV fluids are necessary to address her hemodynamic instability, she also requires surgical intervention.
✅ Refer for emergency surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.    
❌ Obtain transvaginal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Transvaginal ultrasound should be obtained in hemodynamically stable patients who are suspected for ectopic pregnancy. Since this patient is unstable and the abdominal ultrasound is positive for free fluid in the abdomen, the next best step is surgery consultation and emergency surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, is admitted to the labor and delivery unit in active labor. This pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus, which was managed with metformin. An hour after admission, the patient delivers a healthy baby weighing 4100 g (9 lb 1 oz). Thirty minutes after the placenta is delivered, blood starts flowing profusely from the vaginal vault. Placental examination reveals it is fully intact. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the uterus is soft and boggy. A large-bore IV catheter is inserted, followed by fluid and blood resuscitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postpartum hemorrhage following the delivery of the placenta. The physical examination reveals a boggy, soft uterus, which is consistent with the diagnosis of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony.  

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is an obstetric emergency and is one of the most common causes of maternal mortality. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as 500 ml of blood loss following a vaginal delivery, or more than 1000 ml of blood loss after a C-section. The definitive management of PPH depends on the underlying cause. The most common causes of postpartum hemorrhage can be remembered as 4 T’s - tone (i.e. uterine atony), trauma (i.e. lacerations), tissue (i.e. retained products of conception), and thrombin (i.e. coagulopathy). The most common cause of PPH is uterine atony. Normally, after delivery, the uterus continues to contract, which clamps the spiral arteries and reduces uterine bleeding. Risk factors for uterine atony are factors that cause overdistention of the uterus such as multiparity, greater than 4 previous deliveries, previous C-section or uterine surgery, polyhydramnios, large fetus (as seen in this patient), anesthetic drugs, and prolonged labor. The diagnosis of uterine atony is made clinically by demonstrating a boggy, soft and enlarged uterus while excluding other sites of bleeding. Initial management includes maternal stabilization, uterine massage and oxytocin (1st line); 2nd line agents include methylergonovine and surgical interventions.



Option Analysis

❌ Administer methylergonovine:
Incorrect: Methylergonovine is a uterotonic and analgesic used in postpartum hemorrhage secondary to uterine atony to control the bleeding. However, it is not first-line treatment and should be used if other measurements have failed. 
❌ Perform suction curettage :
Incorrect: Suction curettage is used if there are retained products of conception, such as retained placenta. The diagnosis is made when the placenta is not expelled 30 minutes following delivery. This patient’s presentation (e.g. soft, boggy uterus) is more consistent with uterine atony. 
❌ Placing a tamponade balloon:
Incorrect: Balloon tamponade is a method that involves the insertion and inflation of a balloon to mechanically control postpartum hemorrhage. It is indicated in patients who have failed uterine massage and uterotonic agents. It can also be used if there is a delay in the administration of uterotonic agents or to decrease bleeding while waiting for interventional radiology or surgical options.
❌ Administer tranexamic acid:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an anti-fibrinolytic agent commonly used in postpartum hemorrhage and traumatic bleeding. However, other measures should be performed prior to this. 
✅ Perform uterine massage :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the clinic at 28 weeks of gestation for a follow-up appointment. Two weeks ago, her blood pressure readings were 145/95 and 146/93 respectively on 2 separate occasions. At the time, a urinalysis showed protein excretion of 300 mg/24 hr and liver function tests and full blood count were within normal limits. Vitals at the clinic today show a temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse of 95/min, and blood pressure of 161/110 mmHg. She currently feels well and discloses only mild occasional headaches.  She denies any visual changes, urinary symptoms or abdominal pain. Physical examination is within normal limits. Non-stress tests are reactive without decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s elevated blood pressure?
questions.solution:
This patient has preeclampsia, defined as new-onset hypertension with either proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks gestation. Preeclampsia can be further classified as preeclampsia without severe features or preeclampsia with severe features. Severe features include systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≥160 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ≥110 mmHg, symptoms of central nervous system dysfunction (e.g. severe headache), hepatic abnormality (e.g., severe persistent right upper quadrant pain, elevated liver enzymes), thrombocytopenia (<100,000 platelets/microL), renal insufficiency, and pulmonary edema. In general, preeclampsia with severe features is an indication for delivery at ≥ 34 weeks of gestation, while patients without severe features are delivered at ≥37 weeks of gestation.  

Regardless of the type of preeclampsia, antihypertensive therapy is currently indicated in pregnancy for blood pressure SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg. Patients with comorbidities may initiate treatment earlier. Drugs that are safe to use during pregnancy include hydralazine, methyldopa, clonidine, labetalol, and nifedipine (helpful mnemonic: “Hypertensive Moms Can Love Nifedipine!”). Intravenous labetalol and hydralazine are first-line agents for acute therapy of severe hypertension.



Option Analysis

❌ Magnesium sulfate :
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for the prevention of seizures, also known as eclampsia. Currently, there is no consensus regarding the optimal magnesium regimen. Magnesium may be administered at the onset of labor, induction, or prior to C-section delivery. It is not routinely given to stable antepartum patients, though it is occasionally given to patients with preeclampsia with severe features who are being considered for expectant management. While administering magnesium is not incorrect in this case, it will not actually treat this patient’s blood pressure, as it has minimal effects on blood pressure.
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril (an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor [ACEi]), angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs), and direct renin inhibitors are routinely used in non-pregnant patients with elevated blood pressures; however, they are contraindicated during pregnancy due to significant risk for fetal renal abnormalities. 
❌ Losartan:
Incorrect: Losartan (angiotensin II receptor blockers [ARBs]), angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and direct renin inhibitors are routinely used in non-pregnant patients with elevated blood pressures; however, they are contraindicated during pregnancy due to significant risk for fetal renal abnormalities. 
✅ Labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nitroprusside :
Incorrect: Nitroprusside is used in hypertensive emergencies. Due to the risk of fetal cyanide poisoning, it is not routinely used in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, gives birth to a healthy 3400 g boy. Four hours later, she suddenly develops a generalized seizure. The pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia, which was managed with lifestyle modifications. Medical history is unremarkable, but her partner states that during the past day, the patient has been experiencing headache and blurry vision. Current temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears drowsy. Cranial nerves are intact. Reflexes are +3 bilaterally, and clonus is present. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with postpartum eclampsia, as indicated by her hypertension and onset of seizures.    

Eclampsia refers to the new-onset of generalized, tonic-clonic seizure or coma in a woman with prior preeclampsia. The exact cause of eclamptic seizures is not entirely understood, but it is hypothesized to be related to a dysfunctional autoregulatory system of the cerebral circulation which results in vasogenic and/or cytotoxic edema. The majority of patients experience a prodrome of signs and symptoms in the hours before the initial seizure which includes hypertension, headache, visual disturbances, right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, ankle clonus, and altered mentation. Some patients may be asymptomatic. Eclampsia can occur preterm, intrapartum or postpartum. Management is aimed to prevent maternal hypoxia and trauma, treat the hypertension, prevent recurrent seizures, and evaluate the necessity of prompt delivery. Magnesium sulfate is a first-line medication that works by stabilizing excitable membranes and preventing seizure recurrence. In cases refractory to magnesium sulfate, 2nd-line drugs are indicated (e.g., amobarbital, thiopental, or phenytoin).    

Pregnancy-related hypertensive disorders such as preeclampsia are associated with obstetric complications such as growth restriction, preterm delivery, abruptio placentae, and stillbirth. Women with pregnancy-related hypertensive disorders are also at increased risk for hypertension, cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease, renal failure, and diabetes.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is a hypertensive medication commonly used in pregnancy. Current guidelines include hypertensive therapy to prevent stroke when SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg. However, hydralazine does not prevent the recurrence of seizures, and therefore, another medication is urgently needed at this time.
✅ Magnesium sulfate :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amobarbital :
Incorrect: Barbiturates work by facilitating GABA action by increasing the duration of chloride channel opening, ultimately decreasing neuron firing. In eclampsia, drugs such as amobarbital are considered 2nd line treatment for refractory cases not responding to magnesium sulfate administration. 
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anti-seizure medication that works by altering sodium movement across the cell membranes in the motor cortex, therefore decreasing seizure activity. In eclampsia, it is considered 2nd line treatment for refractory cases not responding to magnesium sulfate administration. 
❌ Calcium gluconate :
Incorrect: Calcium gluconate is an antidote used for magnesium toxicity by regulating action potential threshold in nerve and muscle cells. Signs and symptoms suggestive of magnesium toxicity include absent patellar reflex, respiratory rate ≤12 breaths/min, flushing, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman at 37-weeks gestation is undergoing a scheduled cesarean section. The patient is prepped and draped, and a horizontal incision with slight convexity is made at the pubic hairline. The remainder of the procedure proceeds without complication. Several hours after the procedure, the patient begins experiencing severe right flank pain and lightheadedness. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 92/66 mmHg, and pulse is 109/min. Physical examination demonstrates a large area of ecchymosis over the right flank. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates a large rectus sheath hematoma with extravasation into the retroperitoneal space. Which of the following intraoperative actions could have prevented this patient’s complication?

choices.text: Ligation of the inferior epigastric artery
Incision made above the arcuate line
Ligation of the common iliac artery
Ligation of the right superior epigastric artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a large rectus sheath hematoma following a cesarean section. This complication was most likely caused by failure to ligate the inferior epigastric arteries, a key step of this common obstetric procedure.

Injury to the inferior epigastric artery may occur with incisions or surgical procedures performed below the arcuate line, as the artery crosses the lateral border of the rectus muscle to enter the posterior rectus sheath. This artery is a branch of the external iliac artery and is a major vascular supply to the anterior abdominal wall.

Procedures performed below the arcuate line include cesarean sections, hysterectomies, laparoscopies, and bowel resections. Horizontal incisions performed during these procedures are at risk of injuring the inferior epigastric vessels and thus must be identified and ligated intraoperatively. Failure to do so may result in the formation of rectus sheath hematomas and ongoing hemorrhage as blood dissects into the retroperitoneum.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ligation of the inferior epigastric artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incision made above the arcuate line:
Incorrect: An incision made above the arcuate line reflects improper surgical technique for a Pfannenstiel incision. Transverse incisions above the arcuate line are indicated only in select upper abdominal surgeries.  
❌ Cross clamping the aorta:
Incorrect: Cross clamping the aorta is not indicated during an elective cesarean section. This surgical technique is only indicated during resuscitative thoracotomy or major aortic surgeries.  
❌ Ligation of the common iliac artery  :
Incorrect: Ligation of the common iliac artery would result in arterial insufficiency of the lower extremity. It is not a component of performing a cesarean section.  
❌ Ligation of the right superior epigastric artery:
Incorrect: The right superior epigastric artery branches from the internal thoracic artery, traverses the rectus sheath at the seventh costal cartilage, and descends on the posterior surface of the rectus muscle. This artery is not at risk of injury during a cesarean section.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old, gravida 2 para 1 at 34 weeks gestation, comes to the emergency department due to colicky abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting for the past day. She also feels generalized malaise and describes it as “more than usual.” The patient’s current pregnancy has been uncomplicated, other than an upper respiratory infection a week ago. Her first pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia, which was managed with antihypertensive medications. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/100 mmHg. On physical examination, right upper quadrant and epigastric tenderness are noted. The conjunctiva is pale and non-icteric. Laboratory results are shown below:



Which of the following tests is most likely to assist in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, thrombocytopenia, low hemoglobin, and elevated direct bilirubin levels and liver enzymes, favoring the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome.    

Hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelet count (HELLP) syndrome is a medical condition seen in pregnant and postpartum women; it is thought to represent a severe form of preeclampsia. The exact pathogenesis of HELLP syndrome is unclear. Microangiopathy and activation of intravascular coagulation are responsible for the laboratory findings in HELLP syndrome. The activation of the coagulation cascade results in the consumption of platelets, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen as schistocytes on peripheral smear. Risk factors for developing HELLP syndrome include a previous history of preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome. Patients often present with midepigastrium/right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and generalized malaise. Less commonly, headaches, visual changes, jaundice, and ascites may occur. Complications of HELLP syndrome are abruptio placentae, acute kidney injury, subcapsular liver hematoma/hepatic rupture, and pulmonary edema.  



Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound can be used in the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. While patients with cholecystitis can present with colicky abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, the presence of high blood pressure, low hemoglobin, low platelets, and elevated liver enzymes raises concern for HELLP syndrome. 
❌ Lipase and amylase levels :
Incorrect: Lipase and amylase levels can be helpful in establishing the diagnosis of pancreatitis. However, this patient is presenting with high blood pressure, low hemoglobin, low platelets and elevated liver enzymes, which raises concern for HELLP syndrome. 
❌ Liver biopsy  :
Incorrect: Liver biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), which can occasionally be difficult to distinguish from HELLP syndrome. However, liver biopsy is an invasive test and rarely used. Also, AFLP will likely present with fever, liver failure, encephalopathy, and severe hypoglycemia.
✅ Peripheral smear:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ADAMTS13 activity and inhibitor testing:
Incorrect: ADAMTS13 activity and inhibitor testing can assist in the diagnosis of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). TTP is caused due to deficiency of the ADAMTS13 protease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. TTP typically presents with a triad of thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury, as well as fever and neurologic symptoms. While some of this patient’s symptoms overlap with TTP, the absence of fever and neurologic signs makes this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, liver enzymes are minimally elevated in TTP.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman is evaluated by an obstetrician after delivering a healthy baby 24 hours ago. The delivery was complicated by protraction in the first labor stage and augmented by an infusion bolus of oxytocin. After delivery, she suffered from excessive postpartum bleeding, which was successfully managed with oxytocin infusion and bimanual uterine massage. Which of the following side effects might develop as a result of oxytocin administration?
questions.solution:
This patient was administered oxytocin for labor induction and to treat her postpartum hemorrhage–increasing the risk of developing associated side effects. One known side effect is the development of hyponatremia.

Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the hypothalamus and stored and released in the posterior pituitary. It stimulates uterine contraction by binding to Gq protein-coupled receptors. Once activated, these receptors activate another molecule called phospholipase C. Phospholipase C cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5 bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate. Finally, inositol triphosphate promotes the opening of calcium channels in the endoplasmic reticulum, enhancing calcium release into the cytoplasm, which mediates the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated for both ante- and postpartum conditions. In the antepartum period, oxytocin is administered to strengthen uterine contractions to induce or facilitate labor. Oxytocin is also administered to treat postpartum hemorrhage as it mediates the contraction of the uterus and subsequent closure of uterine vasculature.

Side effects of oxytocin include vasodilation, which may result in hypotension and tachycardia. In addition, patients may develop water retention and hyponatremia. This occurs secondary to the ability of oxytocin to act on antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the renal tubules, promoting free water retention. Finally, oxytocin can lead to tachysystole (5 or more contractions in 10 minutes over a 30-minute duration).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: When oxytocin is administered excessively or for prolonged periods, it acts similarly to antidiuretic hormone, promoting free water reabsorption and hyponatremia.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is not a side effect of oxytocin.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid (TXA) is sometimes used in patients with severe postpartum hemorrhage. TXA is an antifibrinolytic medication that prevents blood clots from breaking down. VTE is not a known side effect of oxytocin administration.  
❌ Bronchoconstriction:
Incorrect: Bronchoconstriction is a known side effect of prostaglandins and prostaglandin analogs (carboprost).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 31 weeks gestation, gravida 1 para 0, is admitted to the delivery unit due to preterm labor. The patient presented with regular uterus contractions and evidence of cervical dilation. Her pregnancy was uneventful, and she has regularly followed up with her prenatal care. The physician starts the patient on indomethacin and betamethasone. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of indomethacin?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium
Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus

questions.solution:
This patient presented in preterm labor and was administered indomethacin to delay labor and allow for timely administration of glucocorticoids.

Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX), which are responsible for the synthesis of prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for uterine contraction.

Indomethacin can be used as a tocolytic only if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks. After 32 weeks, prostaglandins are contraindicated, as they may lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus. In addition, indomethacin inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins in other organs like the stomach, increasing the risk of gastritis and gastric bleeding. Indomethacin can also induce placental dysfunction (due to vasoconstriction).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks oxytocin receptors:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor that blocks the synthesis of prostaglandins. It does not affect oxytocin receptors.  
❌ Increase the prostaglandin synthesis:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor resulting in decreased prostaglandins synthesis.  
❌ Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium:
Incorrect: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium, resulting in decreased intracellular calcium and, therefore, inhibition of the uterine contractions.  
❌ Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is another tocolytic that stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus. Indomethacin does not exert any effects on this receptor.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 10 weeks of gestational age presents to the emergency department at noon with heavy vaginal bleeding and severe pelvic pain. This morning, she soaked through four pads in an hour and passed multiple large clots, some of which appeared to contain tissue—though she has been using the same pad for the past two hours. The pain is currently rated a 5 on a 10-point scale, though at its peak, it was a 9 and radiated to her lower back and thighs. An ultrasound performed two weeks ago showed a viable fetus with cardiac activity. The medical history is notable for three prior uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. On exam, the cervical os is closed and several small blood clots are visible in the vagina. Lab results are shown below. An ultrasound shows a thickened endometrial lining without an intrauterine fluid collection; the adnexa appear grossly normal. IV fluids and analgesics are administered. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

 Laboratory test  Result 
 Blood type  A-negative 
 Hemoglobin  10.8 g/dL 
 Platelets  304,000/mm3 
 Prothrombin time  12 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time  30 sec
questions.solution:
This patient has a complete miscarriage (closed os and empty uterus after heavy bleeding), and she is Rh negative. Therefore, expectant management and treatment with Rh immune globulin to prevent alloimmunization in future pregnancies is the most appropriate management.    

The management choice is determined by the type of miscarriage. Expectant management is indicated for stable patients with threatened or complete miscarriage, while surgical management is indicated for unstable patients and those with infections.    

For stable patients with asymptomatic (i.e. missed), inevitable, or incomplete pregnancy loss, all three management strategies (i.e. expectant, medical, and surgical) are appropriate and patient preference should guide the decision. Medical management of an early miscarriage involves the use of misoprostol, which induces uterine contractions to expel the products of conception. If available, pre-treatment with mifepristone is recommended because it reduces the risk of retained products of conception. This option allows patients to better control the timing and setting of their miscarriage while avoiding a surgical procedure. A suction dilation and curettage (D&C) is considered definitive management with the lowest failure rate and is associated with lower amounts of bleeding and faster resolution of symptoms. Some patients may determine these benefits outweigh the inherent risks of surgery.  

All patients, including those undergoing expectant management, should be counseled on warning signs that require evaluation. These include heavy bleeding (soaking at least two pads per hour for at least two hours in a row), prolonged bleeding (bleeding persisting beyond two to three weeks), pain uncontrolled with pain medication, fever, or abnormal/foul-smelling discharge.    

Additionally, regardless of the management option chosen, Rh immune globulin should be administered to all Rh-negative patients at risk of alloimmunization. This includes all patients undergoing a procedure during pregnancy (e.g. D&C for early pregnancy loss) and those with uterine bleeding, especially after 7 weeks of gestational age. Alloimmunization refers to the development of antibodies in maternal serum against antigens on fetal red blood cells, which can occur when fetal and maternal blood come into contact with one another. Once alloimmunized, these maternal antibodies may attack any future Rh-positive fetus, resulting in severe fetal anemia and/or pregnancy loss. In the U.S., Rh immune globulin is usually given routinely to any Rh-negative patient who experiences bleeding during pregnancy. However, it should be noted that international guidelines regarding the use of Rh immune globulin in the first trimester vary.  



Option Analysis

✅ Rh-immune globulin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blood transfusion:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically stable and her bleeding has slowed, so a blood transfusion is not needed at this time. It is important to remember, however, that lab values may be falsely reassuring in patients with acute hemorrhage. This is why it is important to look at the entire clinical picture, especially the vital signs and exam findings.
❌ Serum human chorionic gonadotropin level (hCG):
Incorrect: This patient had a prior ultrasound at 8 weeks that showed fetal cardiac activity (FCA). FCA confirms fetal viability, so once FCA has been seen on an ultrasound, hCG levels are no longer necessary. If drawn, however, low levels would support the diagnosis of pregnancy loss.
❌ Misoprostol:
Incorrect: This patient is stable and has a complete miscarriage, so expectant management is recommended. The endometrium will often appear thick initially; however, it will return to normal over the next few days to weeks as bleeding resolves. Medical (or surgical) management is not required simply to address a thickened endometrial lining in an otherwise stable patient.
❌ Suction dilation and curettage (D&C):
Incorrect: This patient is clinically stable despite the amount of bleeding she had at home. Expectant management is appropriate at this time, though a D&C may be indicated later if bleeding does not continue to improve or if she becomes unstable, develops an infection, or has evidence of retained products of conception.
